caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW LEST WE FORGET (FROM SARBAH TO OLLENNU) [1
summary: This 1989–90 Ghana Law Review article, 'Lest We Forget: From Sarbah to Ollennu,' authored by Mr. E.D. Kom, SAG, reflects on the historical contributions of prominent Ghanaian legal figures from the late 19th century to the late 20th century. It highlights John Mensah Sarbah as a pioneering lawyer, educationist, nationalist, and patriot who opposed colonial land legislation, notably the 1897 Lands Bill, and co-founded the Aborigines’ Rights Protection Society (ARPS). The article praises Sarbah’s selfless service, including his refusal of a 400-guinea fee, and his seminal works such as *Fanti Customary Laws*. It also honors other legal luminaries like J.E. Casely Hayford, Dr. J.B. Danquah, and Justice Nii Amaa Ollennu, emphasizing their roles in shaping Ghana’s legal and political landscape. The piece underscores the enduring legacy of lawyers in defending human rights, promoting education, and advancing nationalism, while lamenting contemporary attacks on the legal profession.
rationaleHighlights: Lawyers have historically played a vital role in defending rights and opposing oppressive laws.
Sarbah’s work in customary law remains foundational for Ghanaian jurisprudence.
The legal profession in Ghana has deep roots in nationalism and public service.
Selfless legal advocacy, as exemplified by Sarbah, sets ethical standards for the bar.
Colonial laws like the 1897 Lands Bill threatened indigenous land rights and were resisted by early Ghanaian lawyers.
Dr. J.B. Danquah’s legal arguments in detention cases became a lasting legacy despite judicial rejection.
The article calls for remembrance of legal pioneers to inspire contemporary legal practice.
Legal scholarship and education are central to national development.
confidenceNotes: The document is a scholarly legal commentary rather than a judicial decision, so standard case elements like verdict and prosecution are not applicable. Information is drawn from historical accounts and reputable sources cited within the text, including works by Justice Azu Crabbe and references to court cases. Confidence in factual accuracy is high due to the author's authoritative position and consistent alignment with known legal history.
